clinical_study.brief_title: An Analysis of Presentation and Outcome Following Treatment of Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms
clinical_study.official_title: A Single Centre Analysis of Clinical Characteristics and Treatment of Endocrine Pancreatic Tumours.

brief_summary.textblock: A single institutional study of Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms over 18 years.

detailed_description.textblock: The investigators did an analysis from a prospectively maintained database of patients who underwent pancreatic resections or nonresective procedures for neoplasms of the pancreas at Sir Ganga Ram Hospital from 1995 to 2013 and using pathological reports and preoperative CT scan as the gold standard, the investigators identified 40 patients with PENs.

primary_outcome.measure: Nonfunctioning and Malignant Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Each participant was followed up for a period of 5 years
primary_outcome.description: Of the 40 patients operated for Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms, using clinical criteria, histopathological analysis and preoperative imaging as gold standard, nonfunctioning and functioning tumours were identified. Similarly the number of benign and malignant lesions identified were recorded as per the WHO Classification of pancreatic endocrine tumours.

arm_group.description: We did an observational analysis from a prospectively maintained database of patients who underwent pancreatic surgery for neoplasms of the pancreas at Sir Ganga Ram Hospital, New Delhi, India from 1995 to 2013 and using pathological reports and preoperative CT scan as gold standard, we identified 40 patients with PENs.

study_pop.textblock: Medical files and electronic records were reviewed to collect information. Patients were categorized into functioning and nonfunctioning PENs based on their clinical behaviour, pathology reports and serum radioimmunoassay for offending hormones. Preoperative CT scans were used to characterize PENs and record neoplasm size and location in the pancreas. Review of operative notes was done for the type of surgery performed and peroperative findings recorded. Discharge summaries were used to study the surgical outcome in terms of duration of postoperative hospital stay and postoperative complications. Patients were followed up and any disease recurrence or disease related mortality was recorded. Evaluation of the pathology reports was done.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pathological reports and Prooperative CAT Scan showing Endocrine Pancreatic Tumours
Exclusion Criteria:
- Nonendocrine Pancreatic Tumours

reported_events.time_frame: Complications were noted within the hospital admission. Postoperative mortality recorded as death within the same hospital admission or within 30 days of surgery. Follow up was done at 3 and 6 months and then at 6 monthly intervals for 5 years.
reported_events.desc: The type of surgery performed, operative findings, postoperative hospital stay and complications were recorded. Postoperative mortality was recorded and followup done for disease recurrence or mortality.

event.description: A pancreatic fistula was defined as drainage of more than 30 mL of fluid per day with amylase levels at least 3 times the normal serum amylase levels from the sixth postoperative day
Delayed gastric emptying was defined as intolerance to oral feeds requiring nasogastric aspiration after the sixth postoperative day.
Postoperative fever was defined as core body temperature more than 100 F sustained enough to require medication and search for its cause after surgery.
Wound Infection was defined as purulent discharge from the main wound with positive culture report.
Intraabdominal Abscess was defined as purulent fluid of any amount inside the abdomen requiring percutaneous drainage or laparotomy.
